Developers can embrace four key actions to help navigate this changing environment.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Felectric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas%2Four%20insights%2Foffshore%20wind%20strategies%20for%20uncertain%20times%2Foffshore-wind-strategies-for-uncertain-times.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="offshore-wind-strategies-for-uncertain-times" data-layer-report-name="offshore-wind-strategies-for-uncertain-times>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (8 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>The offshore wind industry</strong> is at an inflection point. Having proved to be an increasingly scalable source of renewable energy, the industry has enjoyed a decade of growth and value creation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="806a9880-98d1-4a07-bad6-87a0472036b3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="806a9880-98d1-4a07-bad6-87a0472036b3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Renewable capacity statistics 2023</em>, International Renewable Energy Agency, March 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Offshore wind is a clean renewable energy sourceâone of the least CO<sub>2</sub>-intensive forms of electricity generation, on par with onshore windâand can help communities around the world meet their net-zero targets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="027b151d-1c8c-45e5-a7d9-05bc4949ce30"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="027b151d-1c8c-45e5-a7d9-05bc4949ce30" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Life cycle greenhouse gas emissions from electricity generation: Update</em>, NREL, September 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons___eQy6"><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="Expandable Sidebar" type="button" id="button_id" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost data-layer-subcategory="open" data-layer-text="open sidebar"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--radial___y3csX_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-xxl___cL3ZT_990311c mck-plus-no-circle-icon"></span></button></div></div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/alexander-weiss">Alexander Weiss</a>, Andreas Schlosser, <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bd8e82147-7bf3-4e5c-b749-dae53b50d9d2%7d%40en">Florian KÃ¼hn</a>, and <a href="/our-people/jakub-zivansky">Jakub Zivansky</a>, with Knut M. Aanstad and Sverre Akersveen, representing views from McKinseyâs Electric Power & Natural Gas Practice.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>However, the current macroeconomic environment is impacting the offshore wind industry, putting pressure on its growth and profitability.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="44285b35-ac74-47eb-a0d3-b5ef07cef11b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="44285b35-ac74-47eb-a0d3-b5ef07cef11b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âGlobal offshore wind farm database and intelligence,â TSG powered by 4C Offshore, accessed February 2022 to September 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Recently, stakeholders have questioned the outlook of the industry after seeing a relatively high density of project cancellations following communicated cost increases of between 40 and 60 percent. Can offshore wind costs rapidly return to attractive levels, or is the cost advantage of onshore wind and solar too large, despite offshore windâs favorable production profiles?</p>
<p>In this article, we discuss why the industry has been so hard hit and when it could reemerge into structural profitability. We delve into potential scenariosâbased on in-depth discussions with industry executives and leadersâthat could affect the outlook of the industry. We conclude with key steps that developers can take to ensure ongoing growth.</p>
<h2>Offshore wind is coming off a decade of strong value creation</h2>
<p>In the 2010s, the offshore wind industry experienced significant growth, making this technology increasingly affordable. The industry has understandably held an optimistic view of the future. Developers have remained profitable and seen volume growth year after year. Governments have viewed offshore wind as a complementary and clean source of energy, with potential to play a major role in the energy transition. Last year, global government targets for total installed capacity by 2030 exceeded 400 gigawatts [GW] (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/offshore%20wind%20strategies%20for%20uncertain%20times/svgz-offshore-winds-exhibits-ex1-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Capacity growth expectations have seen significant increases to 2023, which marked the first year of down-adjusted expectations." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/offshore%20wind%20strategies%20for%20uncertain%20times/svgz-offshore-winds-exhibits-ex1-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The global commissioned capacity of offshore wind increased from 3 GW in 2010 to approximately 66 GW in 2023âroughly enough capacity to meet Spainâs electricity demand, assuming a capacity factor of 45 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="de481c8d-1882-442e-aae0-0702f29be988"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="de481c8d-1882-442e-aae0-0702f29be988" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âGlobal offshore wind farm database and intelligence,â accessed September 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> During this period, the cost of generation for offshore wind decreased by around 60 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2ba6db2c-63bb-4c92-9b03-758b908ca1a7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2ba6db2c-63bb-4c92-9b03-758b908ca1a7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Renewable power generation costs in 2022</em>, International Renewable Energy Agency, August 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> This dramatic reduction in cost was driven by increased competition, low interest rates, and technology development and industrialization.</p>
<p>The industry holds significant room for growth; in theory, there is potential for 20,000 GW of fixed offshore wind, in addition to 50,000 GW of floating offshore wind capacity globally.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="62cd92e2-221e-49ec-9d1b-85b5f00093ce"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="62cd92e2-221e-49ec-9d1b-85b5f00093ce" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âOffshore wind technical potential, analysis and maps,â Energy Sector Management Assistance Program, March 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> It offers a way to generate electricity near coastal load centers, thereby reducing overall transmission costs. These regions are significant in that they make up about 40 percent of the population in offshore markets in the European Union and the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7825289f-d94f-4170-91cc-314c7a568fe3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7825289f-d94f-4170-91cc-314c7a568fe3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âWhat percentage of the American population lives near the coast?,â National Ocean Service, January 20, 2023; Isabelle Collet and Andries Engelbert, âCoastal regions: People living along the coastline, integration of NUTS 2010 and latest population grid,â Eurostat, December 18, 2013.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/how-we-help-clients">Electric Power & Natural Gas Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/how-we-help-clients/renewable-energy-new-downstream" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Renewable Energy & New Downstream page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>The industry has been hard hit by the macroeconomic environment</h2>
<p>Recent macroeconomic trendsârising raw commodity prices, interest rate hikes, and supply chain bottlenecksâhave put pressure on offshore wind developersâ profitability. This vulnerability is largely due to the industryâs exposure to material costs, which has impacted financing costs and slowed down growth, especially in Europe and the United States.</p>
<p>As a result, our analysis shows that since the beginning of the decade many developers have experienced inflated project costs, with communicated levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) increases of around 40 to 60 percent compared to 2020. Further, many projects have contracts for difference (CfD) that are not inflation adjusted, rendering these projects unprofitable.</p>
<p>The industry is experiencing severe consequencesâfor example, only about 40 percent of capacity that was expected to reach a final investment decision (FID) in February 2022 had taken FID by the end of 2023.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ebea6289-1c47-4647-a29b-64ff13ada065"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ebea6289-1c47-4647-a29b-64ff13ada065" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âGlobal offshore wind farm database and intelligence,â accessed September 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition to these delays, projects have been canceled in markets such as the United Kingdom and the US East Coast.</p>
<h2>The role of offshore wind in future energy systems depends on progress across five dimensions</h2>
<p>Following the macroeconomic shocks, it is uncertain when the industry will achieve structural profitability again. We see five drivers impacting the future of the industry: the position on the cost curve, the regulatory landscape, market pull, supply chain capacity, and developer behavior. These drivers can help us understand recent and future developments in the offshore wind industry and what circumstances may affect profitability (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/offshore%20wind%20strategies%20for%20uncertain%20times/svgz-offshore-winds-exhibits-ex2-v10.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The outlook of developer profitability is uncertain going forward, with a wide range of possible outcomes." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/offshore%20wind%20strategies%20for%20uncertain%20times/svgz-offshore-winds-exhibits-ex2-v10.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Position on the cost curve</h3>
<p>Increased material costs, inflation, interest rates, and competitive seabed tenders have increased LCOE expectations. The worsening cost position has created headwinds for the industry, which previously experienced regular year-over-year cost reductions. We have noticed that, as a result, offshore wind developersâ profitability has been affected more so than that of onshore wind and solar developers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="86f0c60a-fb70-41a7-80bc-a90368644662"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="86f0c60a-fb70-41a7-80bc-a90368644662" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinseyâs offshore wind LCOE model.</span></span></span></a></span> Offshore wind has experienced a 10 to 20 percentage point higher increase in costs compared to other renewable technologies, as seen in Germany (Exhibit 3). These same trends are widely observed in Europe and the United States. Even though the inflationary pressure and interest rate expectations have gone down since the beginning of the fourth quarter 2023, the current level of 4.0 to 4.5 percent for the US 10-Year Bond Yield is still at the higher end of the range seen in the previous decade.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dc2e4d94-5f6c-458c-a35f-98ccce179765"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dc2e4d94-5f6c-458c-a35f-98ccce179765" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âCBOE interest rate 10-year T note index,â Yahoo Finance, accessed March 19, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Recently, gas prices have also come down, similar to the levels in Europe before the 2022 energy crisis, challenging the relative affordability of offshore wind in many core markets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="afe5252b-0eef-4afc-847e-bf0b6c5e87fb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="afe5252b-0eef-4afc-847e-bf0b6c5e87fb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âEU natural gas TTF,â Trading Economics, accessed March 19, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/offshore%20wind%20strategies%20for%20uncertain%20times/svgz-offshore-winds-exhibits-ex3-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Offshore wind has been ten to 20 percentage points more exposed to cost-side shocks than other renewable technologies." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/offshore%20wind%20strategies%20for%20uncertain%20times/svgz-offshore-winds-exhibits-ex3-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h3>Regulatory landscape</h3>
<p>Falling CfD strike prices and rising costs of competitive auctions in select regions have led to decreasing attractiveness of offshore wind projects. Strike prices challenge the expected offshore wind LCOE, which adds the risk of discouraging bidders from participation (for example, the United Kingdomâs AR5).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4762d350-3f6b-45e0-8d86-778ebe74b5dd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4762d350-3f6b-45e0-8d86-778ebe74b5dd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The UK ran the CfD auction, with a very low CfD reservation price for offshore wind that did not reflect higher prices of generation. As a result, it did not attract any bidders; Stanley Reed, âNo bidders in British offshore wind auction,â <em>New York Times</em>, September 8, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> We have noticed that developers are attempting to renegotiate CfD contracts, despite obligation to deliver on contracts with governments.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4093d4e7-af97-49e0-b17d-456cebce464c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4093d4e7-af97-49e0-b17d-456cebce464c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nora Buli, âOffshore wind drops out of UK auction on costs, risking climate goals,â Reuters, September 8, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In October and November of 2023, there were signs of significantly increased CfD prices in both the United Kingdom and the United States. The New York October 2023 CfD tender was approximately 50 percent higher than recently seen, while the UK AR6 auction criteria saw an offtake ceiling approximately 66 percent higher than that of AR5.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1310a790-a953-472c-aebf-44df3be79d4e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1310a790-a953-472c-aebf-44df3be79d4e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âGlobal offshore wind farm database and intelligence,â accessed September 2023; âContracts for differences (CfD) allocation round 6: Allocation framework,â UK Department of Energy Security and Net Zero, November 16, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> 2024 will be a crucial year for the industry, with almost 70 GW of project capacity expected to be tendered globally, approximately three times the volume of 2023.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7c93af54-af64-49aa-86a6-dc2d91531c18"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7c93af54-af64-49aa-86a6-dc2d91531c18" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The grand âpriceâ of offshore wind. An assessment of 2024âs tenders and lease auctions</em>, Wood Mackenzie, February 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Market pull</h3>
<p>The market pull for green energy is expected to be an important factor in offshore wind growth and its build-out as a scalable technology. The adoption of regulatory frameworksâsuch as the Renewable Energy Directive III (RED III), the Net-Zero Industry Act (NZIA) in the European Union, and the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) in the United Statesâand other country commitments, will play a central role in the demand for green energy from offshore wind.</p>
<h3>Supply chain capacity</h3>
<p>OEMs in the offshore wind supply chain have in recent years experienced low margins, with indications of insufficient investment in supply chain capacity to meet government targets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fff6304d-ad9b-4724-a73f-a4a909715647"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fff6304d-ad9b-4724-a73f-a4a909715647" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âOffshore wind supply chain constraints,â Wood Mackenzie, September 22, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Turbine OEMs have recently communicated a shift from growth and rapid innovation to a profitability focus going forward, including reducing the number of filed wind power patents and incrementally improving existing technology platforms.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4105463e-b696-4b37-b64c-28ef782d9a3a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4105463e-b696-4b37-b64c-28ef782d9a3a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Vestas CTO says OEMs must focus on optimizing existing tech in order to scale,â WindESCo, October 21, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Suppliers are exposed to sensitivities such as utilization rates, subsidies, and supply chain capital expenditure (capex), as well as uncertain demand. We have seen that modest changes to such factors heavily influence the business case of various players along the supply chain. Improvements in the supply chain will depend on suppliers overcoming these issues in the near future and finding ways to derisk and accelerate investments. In the past months, we have seen early markers of a potential recovery of OEM margins and increased government support to players in the offshore wind supply chain.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a5ac450b-939d-4fbf-8327-1dd3047d36f9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a5ac450b-939d-4fbf-8327-1dd3047d36f9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âWind turbine maker Vestas returns to profit,â Reuters, February 7, 2024; Alexander HÃ¼bner and Christian Kraemer, âGerman government supports Siemens Energy with $8 bln guarantees,â Reuters, November 15, 2023; âEIB commits â¬5 billion to support Europeâs wind manufacturers and approvers over â¬20 billion in financing for new projects,â European Investment Bank, December 13, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Developer behavior</h3>
<p>The global offshore wind developer landscape has become increasingly competitive over the past decade, following times of high profitability and optimism about falling generation costs. In addition, several larger independent power producers (IPPs) and oil and gas players have entered the space. We have noticed that developer competition has put pressure on profitability, driving down subsidies while pushing up the prices of seabed leases. However, between 2021 and 2023, there was a sharp drop in project pipeline realization, which may indicate initial signs of developers being uncertain about future market participation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="79b17fc2-dc32-4286-bbdd-5afb70e02e9d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="79b17fc2-dc32-4286-bbdd-5afb70e02e9d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âGlobal offshore wind farm database and intelligence,â accessed September 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> With delayed or even canceled projects, penalization in financial markets, and reduced internal rate of return (IRR) guidance, the first signs of potential market exits and consolidation may be emerging.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="High voltage pylons with electric power lines transferring electricity from solar photovoltaic sells at sunrise. Production of sustainable energy concept. - stock photo" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/oil%20and%20gas/our%20insights/global%20energy%20perspective%202023/power%20outlook/thumb-gettyimages-1344124162.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Global Energy Perspective 2023: Power outlook</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2023-power-outlook" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>The industry is facing more uncertainty than anticipated: Three possible scenarios</h2>
<p>With the current levels of uncertainty, three conceivable scenarios for the next decade of the industry emerge. These have been developed through numerous discussions with offshore wind clients globally in the past 12 months.</p>
<p><strong>The âstructurally challengedâ scenario</strong> anticipates that developers and regulators cannot solve the current challenges and may gradually prioritize alternative sources of renewable energy that are becoming increasingly cost competitive. In this scenario, there will most likely be a continuation of the pattern of canceled or delayed projects, and frequent market or industry exits.</p>
<p><strong>The âjust for the heroesâ scenario</strong> expects that the industry will continue to grow despite its challenging cost position. Profitability will be structurally reset as the offshore wind margin premium evaporates compared to onshore renewables. In this scenario, industry leaders who are present in the ârightâ markets will be able to realize value-accretive projects.</p>
<p><strong>The âprofitability restorationâ scenario</strong> is one in which market forces help restore industry predictability and profitability, allowing for healthier developer margins in line with announced profitability targets or beyond.</p>
<p>After discussing these scenarios with market participants in the past months, our view is that the industry could be facing a âjust for the heroesâ scenario. In such a scenario, capacity additions will likely fall short of current industry growth expectations, with new projects representing approximately 10 to 15 GW per year over the next decade reaching FIDâ30 to 50 percent lower than many current industry scenarios.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="986796e6-20c3-42ad-980b-129b57b05d11"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="986796e6-20c3-42ad-980b-129b57b05d11" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âGlobal offshore wind farm database and intelligence,â accessed September 2023; <em>Global wind power market outlook update: Q3 2023 report</em>, Wood Mackenzie, September 14, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Large variability in performance between developers and markets could be observed with structural differences in profitability, resulting in less attractive markets gradually being deprioritized. Here, capacity additions will likely take place primarily in mature and self-sustained markets.</p>
<p>The belief in the plausibility of this scenario is based on expected developments in the macroeconomic environment, regulatory landscape, and market pull.</p>
<p>First, the macroeconomic environment is expected to experience prolonged difficulties, with commodity prices and interest rates above 2022 levels. Second, the regulatory landscape might gradually attract more capital, however, the speed of regulatory change will likely be influenced by expected budget constraints. Third, there is a trend toward increasing market pull for green power among transition leaders in select geographies, but cost is expected to remain an important factor.</p>
<p>Other factors, such as the position on the cost curve and supply chain issues, could point toward an even less optimistic scenario for offshore wind. We have also seen limited developer consolidation to dateâhowever, current project cancellations, delays, and market exits might be the first signs of future consolidation.</p>
<p>There are various key trigger events worth monitoring that might have a significant impact on the industryâs futureâincluding the outcome of upcoming seabed and CfD auctions, and commitment in the European Union and the United States to achieving net zero by 2050.</p>
<h2>Thriving in a âjust for the heroesâ scenario</h2>
<p><a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/strategic-courage-in-an-age-of-volatility">Previous McKinsey research</a> points to two types of business leaders that emerge during challenging times.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="98f691b9-f2b5-4a60-bc6b-c10073f8dff3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="98f691b9-f2b5-4a60-bc6b-c10073f8dff3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Michael Birshan, Ishaan Seth, and Bob Sternfels, â<a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/strategic-courage-in-an-age-of-volatility">Strategic courage in an age of volatility</a>,â <em>McKinsey Quarterly</em>, August 29, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The first type is cautious when dealing with volatility and uncertainty. These leaders concentrate on threats in the here and now, focusing on scenario planning, resilience preparation, balance sheet management, near-term efficiency drives, and inflation monitoring. They are in a strategic âwait and watchâ mode as conditions unfold. Most senior executives fall into this category.</p>
<p>The second type of leader takes similar defensive actions, while also leaning into the volatility, using it as a catalyst to grab new opportunities. They think about the next decade, not just the next month, and rethink opportunities and strategy in light of current conditions. Stakeholders in the offshore wind industry could take inspiration from this approach. Of course, there is no silver bullet solution to position for continued value creation, however, there are four value-accretive mindsets that developers and energy companies could explore:</p>
<ol>
    <li><strong>Taking smart and controlled market bets with foresight, while investing in seed options to provide further opportunities in the case of an upswing.</strong> Given the nature and size of offshore wind projects, efficiently deciding on capital allocation across geographies is criticalâfor example, focusing on investments in countries with inflation adjustments and low technology risk. Investing in options for potential build-out in the case of a rapid change in the macroeconomic environment could also be beneficial. In addition, it would be critical to invest in bidding excellence and understand how to develop a strong value proposition for nonprice criteria.</li>
    <li><strong>Developing an active stance on consolidation.</strong> Developers could carefully assess potential inorganic opportunities and, if possible, explore the feasibility of investing anticyclically to rebalance growth.</li>
    <li><strong>Focusing on maximizing efficiency to prepare for a future horizon of lower structural profitability.</strong> Developers could explore new organizational structures to quickly adapt to the shifting circumstances of the offshore wind market and consider identifying opportunities to increase performance across development expenses, operating and capital expenditures, as well as pursuing financial discipline.</li>
    <li><strong>Establishing strategic supply chain collaborations, creating transparency and predictability.</strong> Developers could explore supply chain collaboration, including vertical integration of strategic suppliers and direct sourcing from tier two and tier three suppliers. Energy companies could create transparency on project pipelines with OEMs and key suppliers, establish strategic partnerships to secure volumes, and carefully explore and assess technical improvements and value-creation opportunities in the supply chain.</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p>The offshore wind industry is facing significant challenges in the current macroeconomic environment. However, developers can take steps to navigate this changing landscape to ensure continued growth. By taking smart market bets, actively considering consolidation, maximizing efficiency, and collaborating strategically with suppliers, developers can position themselves to thrive in volatile times. While the industryâs future profitability is uncertain, there are early signs of improvement, and we remain optimistic about the potential of offshore wind as a clean and renewable energy source.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/alexander-weiss">Alexander Weiss</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinseyâs Berlin office; <strong>Andreas Schlosser</strong> is a partner in the Munich office; <strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bd8e82147-7bf3-4e5c-b749-dae53b50d9d2%7d%40en">Florian KÃ¼hn</a></strong> is a partner in the Oslo office; <strong><a href="/our-people/jakub-zivansky">Jakub Zivansky</a></strong> is a partner in the Prague office; and <strong>Knut Aanstad</strong> is a senior advisor based in the Oslo office, where <strong>Sverre Akersveen</strong> is a consultant.</p>

Developers can embrace four key actions to help navigate this changing environment."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"The offshore wind industry is facing challenges that are halting growth and profitability. Developers can embrace four key actions to help navigate this changing environment"},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-07-12T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe offshore wind industry\u003c/strong\u003e is at an inflection point. Having proved to be an increasingly scalable source of renewable energy, the industry has enjoyed a decade of growth and value creation.[[footnote 1]] Offshore wind is a clean renewable energy source\u0026mdash;one of the least CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e-intensive forms of electricity generation, on par with onshore wind\u0026mdash;and can help communities around the world meet their net-zero targets.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, the current macroeconomic environment is impacting the offshore wind industry, putting pressure on its growth and profitability.[[footnote 3]] Recently, stakeholders have questioned the outlook of the industry after seeing a relatively high density of project cancellations following communicated cost increases of between 40 and 60 percent. Can offshore wind costs rapidly return to attractive levels, or is the cost advantage of onshore wind and solar too large, despite offshore wind\u0026rsquo;s favorable production profiles?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this article, we discuss why the industry has been so hard hit and when it could reemerge into structural profitability. We delve into potential scenarios\u0026mdash;based on in-depth discussions with industry executives and leaders\u0026mdash;that could affect the outlook of the industry. We conclude with key steps that developers can take to ensure ongoing growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eOffshore wind is coming off a decade of strong value creation\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the 2010s, the offshore wind industry experienced significant growth, making this technology increasingly affordable. The industry has understandably held an optimistic view of the future. Developers have remained profitable and seen volume growth year after year. Governments have viewed offshore wind as a complementary and clean source of energy, with potential to play a major role in the energy transition. Last year, global government targets for total installed capacity by 2030 exceeded 400 gigawatts [GW] (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe global commissioned capacity of offshore wind increased from 3 GW in 2010 to approximately 66 GW in 2023\u0026mdash;roughly enough capacity to meet Spain\u0026rsquo;s electricity demand, assuming a capacity factor of 45 percent.[[footnote 4]] During this period, the cost of generation for offshore wind decreased by around 60 percent.[[footnote 5]] This dramatic reduction in cost was driven by increased competition, low interest rates, and technology development and industrialization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe industry holds significant room for growth; in theory, there is potential for 20,000 GW of fixed offshore wind, in addition to 50,000 GW of floating offshore wind capacity globally.[[footnote 6]] It offers a way to generate electricity near coastal load centers, thereby reducing overall transmission costs. These regions are significant in that they make up about 40 percent of the population in offshore markets in the European Union and the United States.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\u003ch2\u003eThe industry has been hard hit by the macroeconomic environment\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecent macroeconomic trends\u0026mdash;rising raw commodity prices, interest rate hikes, and supply chain bottlenecks\u0026mdash;have put pressure on offshore wind developers\u0026rsquo; profitability. This vulnerability is largely due to the industry\u0026rsquo;s exposure to material costs, which has impacted financing costs and slowed down growth, especially in Europe and the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a result, our analysis shows that since the beginning of the decade many developers have experienced inflated project costs, with communicated levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) increases of around 40 to 60 percent compared to 2020. Further, many projects have contracts for difference (CfD) that are not inflation adjusted, rendering these projects unprofitable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe industry is experiencing severe consequences\u0026mdash;for example, only about 40 percent of capacity that was expected to reach a final investment decision (FID) in February 2022 had taken FID by the end of 2023.[[footnote 8]] In addition to these delays, projects have been canceled in markets such as the United Kingdom and the US East Coast.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe role of offshore wind in future energy systems depends on progress across five dimensions\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFollowing the macroeconomic shocks, it is uncertain when the industry will achieve structural profitability again. We see five drivers impacting the future of the industry: the position on the cost curve, the regulatory landscape, market pull, supply chain capacity, and developer behavior. These drivers can help us understand recent and future developments in the offshore wind industry and what circumstances may affect profitability (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch3\u003ePosition on the cost curve\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIncreased material costs, inflation, interest rates, and competitive seabed tenders have increased LCOE expectations. The worsening cost position has created headwinds for the industry, which previously experienced regular year-over-year cost reductions. We have noticed that, as a result, offshore wind developers\u0026rsquo; profitability has been affected more so than that of onshore wind and solar developers.[[footnote 9]] Offshore wind has experienced a 10 to 20 percentage point higher increase in costs compared to other renewable technologies, as seen in Germany (Exhibit 3). These same trends are widely observed in Europe and the United States. Even though the inflationary pressure and interest rate expectations have gone down since the beginning of the fourth quarter 2023, the current level of 4.0 to 4.5 percent for the US 10-Year Bond Yield is still at the higher end of the range seen in the previous decade.[[footnote 10]] Recently, gas prices have also come down, similar to the levels in Europe before the 2022 energy crisis, challenging the relative affordability of offshore wind in many core markets.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch3\u003eRegulatory landscape\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFalling CfD strike prices and rising costs of competitive auctions in select regions have led to decreasing attractiveness of offshore wind projects. Strike prices challenge the expected offshore wind LCOE, which adds the risk of discouraging bidders from participation (for example, the United Kingdom\u0026rsquo;s AR5).[[footnote 12]] We have noticed that developers are attempting to renegotiate CfD contracts, despite obligation to deliver on contracts with governments.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn October and November of 2023, there were signs of significantly increased CfD prices in both the United Kingdom and the United States. The New York October 2023 CfD tender was approximately 50 percent higher than recently seen, while the UK AR6 auction criteria saw an offtake ceiling approximately 66 percent higher than that of AR5.[[footnote 14]] 2024 will be a crucial year for the industry, with almost 70 GW of project capacity expected to be tendered globally, approximately three times the volume of 2023.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMarket pull\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe market pull for green energy is expected to be an important factor in offshore wind growth and its build-out as a scalable technology. The adoption of regulatory frameworks\u0026mdash;such as the Renewable Energy Directive III (RED III), the Net-Zero Industry Act (NZIA) in the European Union, and the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) in the United States\u0026mdash;and other country commitments, will play a central role in the demand for green energy from offshore wind.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSupply chain capacity\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOEMs in the offshore wind supply chain have in recent years experienced low margins, with indications of insufficient investment in supply chain capacity to meet government targets.[[footnote 16]] Turbine OEMs have recently communicated a shift from growth and rapid innovation to a profitability focus going forward, including reducing the number of filed wind power patents and incrementally improving existing technology platforms.[[footnote 17]] Suppliers are exposed to sensitivities such as utilization rates, subsidies, and supply chain capital expenditure (capex), as well as uncertain demand. We have seen that modest changes to such factors heavily influence the business case of various players along the supply chain. Improvements in the supply chain will depend on suppliers overcoming these issues in the near future and finding ways to derisk and accelerate investments. In the past months, we have seen early markers of a potential recovery of OEM margins and increased government support to players in the offshore wind supply chain.[[footnote 18]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDeveloper behavior\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe global offshore wind developer landscape has become increasingly competitive over the past decade, following times of high profitability and optimism about falling generation costs. In addition, several larger independent power producers (IPPs) and oil and gas players have entered the space. We have noticed that developer competition has put pressure on profitability, driving down subsidies while pushing up the prices of seabed leases. However, between 2021 and 2023, there was a sharp drop in project pipeline realization, which may indicate initial signs of developers being uncertain about future market participation.[[footnote 19]] With delayed or even canceled projects, penalization in financial markets, and reduced internal rate of return (IRR) guidance, the first signs of potential market exits and consolidation may be emerging.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up readnext]]\n\u003ch2\u003eThe industry is facing more uncertainty than anticipated: Three possible scenarios\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the current levels of uncertainty, three conceivable scenarios for the next decade of the industry emerge. These have been developed through numerous discussions with offshore wind clients globally in the past 12 months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe \u0026lsquo;structurally challenged\u0026rsquo; scenario\u003c/strong\u003e anticipates that developers and regulators cannot solve the current challenges and may gradually prioritize alternative sources of renewable energy that are becoming increasingly cost competitive. In this scenario, there will most likely be a continuation of the pattern of canceled or delayed projects, and frequent market or industry exits.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe \u0026lsquo;just for the heroes\u0026rsquo; scenario\u003c/strong\u003e expects that the industry will continue to grow despite its challenging cost position. Profitability will be structurally reset as the offshore wind margin premium evaporates compared to onshore renewables. In this scenario, industry leaders who are present in the \u0026ldquo;right\u0026rdquo; markets will be able to realize value-accretive projects.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe \u0026lsquo;profitability restoration\u0026rsquo; scenario\u003c/strong\u003e is one in which market forces help restore industry predictability and profitability, allowing for healthier developer margins in line with announced profitability targets or beyond.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter discussing these scenarios with market participants in the past months, our view is that the industry could be facing a \u0026ldquo;just for the heroes\u0026rdquo; scenario. In such a scenario, capacity additions will likely fall short of current industry growth expectations, with new projects representing approximately 10 to 15 GW per year over the next decade reaching FID\u0026mdash;30 to 50 percent lower than many current industry scenarios.[[footnote 20]] Large variability in performance between developers and markets could be observed with structural differences in profitability, resulting in less attractive markets gradually being deprioritized. Here, capacity additions will likely take place primarily in mature and self-sustained markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe belief in the plausibility of this scenario is based on expected developments in the macroeconomic environment, regulatory landscape, and market pull.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, the macroeconomic environment is expected to experience prolonged difficulties, with commodity prices and interest rates above 2022 levels. Second, the regulatory landscape might gradually attract more capital, however, the speed of regulatory change will likely be influenced by expected budget constraints. Third, there is a trend toward increasing market pull for green power among transition leaders in select geographies, but cost is expected to remain an important factor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther factors, such as the position on the cost curve and supply chain issues, could point toward an even less optimistic scenario for offshore wind. We have also seen limited developer consolidation to date\u0026mdash;however, current project cancellations, delays, and market exits might be the first signs of future consolidation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are various key trigger events worth monitoring that might have a significant impact on the industry\u0026rsquo;s future\u0026mdash;including the outcome of upcoming seabed and CfD auctions, and commitment in the European Union and the United States to achieving net zero by 2050.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThriving in a \u0026lsquo;just for the heroes\u0026rsquo; scenario\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/strategic-courage-in-an-age-of-volatility\"\u003ePrevious McKinsey research\u003c/a\u003e points to two types of business leaders that emerge during challenging times.[[footnote 21]] The first type is cautious when dealing with volatility and uncertainty. These leaders concentrate on threats in the here and now, focusing on scenario planning, resilience preparation, balance sheet management, near-term efficiency drives, and inflation monitoring. They are in a strategic \u0026ldquo;wait and watch\u0026rdquo; mode as conditions unfold. Most senior executives fall into this category.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe second type of leader takes similar defensive actions, while also leaning into the volatility, using it as a catalyst to grab new opportunities. They think about the next decade, not just the next month, and rethink opportunities and strategy in light of current conditions. Stakeholders in the offshore wind industry could take inspiration from this approach. Of course, there is no silver bullet solution to position for continued value creation, however, there are four value-accretive mindsets that developers and energy companies could explore:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTaking smart and controlled market bets with foresight, while investing in seed options to provide further opportunities in the case of an upswing.\u003c/strong\u003e Given the nature and size of offshore wind projects, efficiently deciding on capital allocation across geographies is critical\u0026mdash;for example, focusing on investments in countries with inflation adjustments and low technology risk. Investing in options for potential build-out in the case of a rapid change in the macroeconomic environment could also be beneficial. In addition, it would be critical to invest in bidding excellence and understand how to develop a strong value proposition for nonprice criteria.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDeveloping an active stance on consolidation.\u003c/strong\u003e Developers could carefully assess potential inorganic opportunities and, if possible, explore the feasibility of investing anticyclically to rebalance growth.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFocusing on maximizing efficiency to prepare for a future horizon of lower structural profitability.\u003c/strong\u003e Developers could explore new organizational structures to quickly adapt to the shifting circumstances of the offshore wind market and consider identifying opportunities to increase performance across development expenses, operating and capital expenditures, as well as pursuing financial discipline.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEstablishing strategic supply chain collaborations, creating transparency and predictability.\u003c/strong\u003e Developers could explore supply chain collaboration, including vertical integration of strategic suppliers and direct sourcing from tier two and tier three suppliers. Energy companies could create transparency on project pipelines with OEMs and key suppliers, establish strategic partnerships to secure volumes, and carefully explore and assess technical improvements and value-creation opportunities in the supply chain.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe offshore wind industry is facing significant challenges in the current macroeconomic environment. However, developers can take steps to navigate this changing landscape to ensure continued growth. By taking smart market bets, actively considering consolidation, maximizing efficiency, and collaborating strategically with suppliers, developers can position themselves to thrive in volatile times.
